text:
I had to dig deep to remember this one.

I did a content marketing campaign for a local telecom company.

They had one of the first online video shows in Romania (this was back in 2009) and we created a blog for one of the characters, among other things.

The funny thing is that other bloggers thought the actress in the videos was actually behind the blog. Got a few emails from them hitting on her.

It was seriously funny.

Those were simpler times, weren’t they?
Documenting the process can be incredibly valuable. It depends which audience you’re trying to speak to.

From my perspective, this an opportunity for marketers to start thinking ahead and work on defining KPIs that are less dependent on ad-tech.

I know this is a complicated and thorny issue that’s bound to create tension, especially in bigger companies (organic vs paid) but it’s a debate we need to have in the industry.

Hopefully, less tracking will become the norm, so that leaves us with the challenge of changing the status quo.

What do you worry about the most, Matt?

<@UJG46SBV3> I’ll preface this first by saying that I’m firmly on the production side of my content team. I do a lot of writing, with an equal mix toward SEO-focused stuff like pillar pages and cluster content, and gated pieces like ebooks, guides, and white papers.

My first inclination when I read about this article was what you already gestured at. This feature has the potential to make tracking much more difficult for content marketers, which could in turn domino into greater challenges like proving ROI—something that can be difficult considering many content functions in companies today are understaffed and under-resourced.

I suppose another question I have is, doesn’t a feature like this potentially render the entire practice of gating content obsolete? I know the wind is already blowing in that direction, but it feels like this announcement is accelerating that.

1. Target BOFU keywords, such as these - <https://www.growthramp.io/articles/content-comparative-advertising>
2. Learn who your buyer personas are, and what language they use.
3. Find out what problems they have and questions they want answers to (Quora is a good source once you know the language).
4. Write articles that best answer's their questions.
5. Optimize for a keyword to scale it.
6. Promote it to that audience.

attachments.title: Comparative Advertising: Applying The Art of War to Content Marketing
attachments.text: When done right, comparative advertising will help you win potential customers looking to buy now. Click to learn how to use comparative marketing to for your startup.
attachments.fallback: Comparative Advertising: Applying The Art of War to Content Marketing

text: <@UJG46SBV3> that reminds me of the first Cloverfield movie and how they created MySpace (!) accounts for the characters in the movie, etc. in order to make it feel real.
